text: According to environmental advocates since the 1960s, we're all dead.  Have a look at the predictions made since then, or at least as many as you can stomach since there have been so very, very many of them and nearly all of them have failed or been revised.  Yet the current crop of alarmists will still deliver the "we have to act NOW!" message with the same intensity and fatalism as the previous generation, who copied the one before them, who copied the one before them, ad infinitum.  Ironically, this is the same practice as the religious, who shriek that "Jesus could come today!  Get saved!  There's no time to fact-check!" as they have for thousands of years.  "Climate Change" is the same type of hysteria as the church, adapted for the same goal:  to make money off the emotionalism of those with short memories or little life experience.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text: John Boswell, I want you to know that in my 5th grade class, you are an absolute rock star!  I show SO MANY of your videos to my students all year long (as they fit in with my Next Gen Science Standards!) and we LOVE them!  My students continue to watch your videos at home, and surprise me when they return to class, singing your songs word for word - and imitating the scientists who say them!  And when we have free time, they holler out their favorites to be played: We are Stardust, Secret of the Stars, Monsters of the Cosmos, and SO MANY MORE.   Your videos make me cry, and inspire 10 and 11 year olds like nothing I've ever seen before!  THANK YOU so much!  You, good sir, are most certainly CHANGING THE WORLD!  My highest and most sincere regards, respect, and appreciation!  :-)

text: As a person of this generation, I feel as if that social media and society has greatly shaped what we are going to be. In terms of social media and society, where all there is pop culture and all these famous people who hardly do anything. I appreciate when famous people, say a singer or an athlete did something to help the world with its issues. What I think of my generation is that we are so influenced by others. I hate when people call someone else in my class dumb or retarded because that doesn't solve anything. So we are put down and most of the time always afraid of being different. People want you to be what they want you to be, not what you want to be. I want my classmates or whoever to prosper through knowledge because the world can only be greater when we work towards solving its issues. We must be with one another no matter who or what they are because sometimes even a bit of knowledge is what can lead to whole life time of prosperity

text: ¬†@barrettdc1¬†¬†I honestly recommend you watch some Bernie videos (and videos for the rest of them while you're at it). The word "socialism" doesn't mean what you're thinking it means in this case. People always freak the everliving fuck out when they hear the word related to Bernie, but very few people actually know what it means. It's just a common knowledge problem, really. If we didn't use socialism, we would not have roads, public education, etc. Just imparting something I have come to learn myself recently.
author: LockhartLore

text:
¬†@barrettdc1¬†¬†Hey, I'm just regurgitating that. Those examples really ARE examples of socialism. He doesn't want to "give every person in the country free this, free that." Oh my god, where does that come from? That's insane! The only "free" thing he wants is education, which ABSOLUTELY should be free. It's beyond stupid that it puts people in crippling debt. That's the future of your country right there, and we're making it harder for them to contribute well to this country. The only other thing I can think of is healthcare, which is not ever going to free in the U.S., but it does need to be changed. People here die everyday because they can't afford the healthcare for treatable diseases. We are in a huge amount of debt, yes, but making education and healthcare unattainably expensive is only going to make it worse. There are so many other things we could do instead.¬†

By the way, your last paragraph tells me that you actually might like Bernie, because he feels the same way you do. He accepts no lobbyists or corporation funding. He's funded completely off of his follower's donations, which is why he has no commercials or expensive ad campaigns. That's actually the reason he "lost" the CNN debate despite having many more votes by the public, because the company that owns CNN has money on Hillary while Sanders doesn't accept it.

text: +MastaNinja  global warming is a natural process occurring since the last ice age, it had been continuously warming since then. Humans cannot reverse this massive natural process, they can try to slow it slightly but it's at a great expense to us.
author: Edmonton Rails

text:
¬†@Noah S.¬†¬†It isn't a natural process. Not at this scale. We know that CO2 is what causes the greenhouse effect, and yes this is produced in nature, but civilizations pump out an unnatural amount of it into the atmosphere. It would be impossible for this to have affected nothing.
¬†We've known this since the late 70s and early 80s. What is normally a natural process has been aggravated to the point that it's entirely possible that we won't survive the next climate event, be it an ice age or just climbing greenhouse effect.
author: LockhartLore

text: ¬†@MastaNinja¬†¬† Nature still pumps out alot more, it simply takes it back afterwards. The amount humans put out is way over exaggerated. Even if we cut back massive amounts (That would be ridiculous cost to everyone) it would still warm up until it reaches the point of the cycle where it begins to cool off, just slower.
author: Edmonton Rails

text: +Noah S. i suggest you look at some graphs and charts...  your trying to give nature the credit for the huge rise in Co2? until people came around, the concentration never got over over 300 parts per million, then 1950 comes around, and it does, we're now at about 380 parts per million.  sure, nature contributes. but uh,  I'm pretty sure the numbers don't lie. what we do, and how we do it has a damned large significant impact.
author: DfiantStrike

text: ¬†@DfiantStrike¬†¬† Like I said the earth has been constantly warming since the last ice age, we can try slowing it down with massive amounts of resources and efforts but we can't stop it.¬†
author: Edmonton Rails

text: ¬†@Noah S.¬†¬†The planet's temperature and greenhouse gas content does rise and fall, but it's always done so steadily. The 1950s marked the peak of this era's warming period. Instead of going back down like it was supposed to, it shot up like a rocket due to massive amounts of excess CO2 caused by us. We're supposed to be heading back down again, but we're at well over twice the normal amount of greenhouse gasses and still climbing. I wish I had the charts to show you, but my professor doesn't have them posted. I'm sure they can be found online, though. The reason scientists are flipping their shit is because we're in deep shit. Even if we turn off the spigot of pollution RIGHT THIS SECOND, we are still locked in to an unnaturally warm planet. And if we don't stop, whether or not people in first world countries are a little less comfortable, these numbers will be a lot more scary in just a few years because of the rate of increase we're seeing. They used to think we'd just be inconveniencing our children or our children's children, but now they're saying that's clear that we ourselves will see the end of a sustainable lifestyle. That's why governments are having emergency talks and conferences. It's our reality now.
author: LockhartLore

text: ¬†@Noah S.¬†¬†Here's an article I can link you to:¬†http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-21/2015-was-by-far-hottest-in-modern-times-noaa/7103164

text:
+Robert Anon I disagree with noah. The last ice age was theorized to be many things, and I think it's due to the volcano theory. In my opinion, I don't think that co2 is the main contributor to another ice age, but what I am mostly worried about is our entire atmosphere being turned to mush with no oxygen left and everyone suffocates. However, the conclusion that I am going to make is still the end of the human race and land creatures.

The thing that most people don't seem to realize is that co2 does cause heating. Even if it is due to "sun spots" if we even take a look at Venus for example, it's atmosphere is entirely (okay fine trace amounts of other stuff) made out of co2. That greenhouse effect is clearly obvious. btw venus is one of the hottest planets, hotter than mercury.

Going back to the issue at hand, I also believe that our planet's going to heat up quite badly within 20-30 years due to co2. The question is : is the human race attributed to the weather warming up? My answer is yes. If you take a look at the charts they are very predictable with the co2. Not entirely going up and down but look at the periods. Each period describes exactly what the scientist say that the co2 emissions are at record highs and even more. The only thing that could have caused this is due to human interaction. That's THE ONLY variable is human race being active with fossil fuels.

text: +Noah S. by starting it you mean, the sun was made? Because heat doesn't normally come out of nowhere....

text: +Noah S. like I said, I am just worried about our atmosphere turning into a venus. Of course it's natural, but that's why we need to change it. And before you say : "we don't know much about venus" there's recently an article about how cold venus can also be at night. I fear that it's worse than we originally thought. But we are in fact putting to much co2. I highly doubt that 20-25ppm within 10 years is deniable to human co2 impacts.

text:
+Jayced Up Let's list the facts about this conversation.

1. Garrett was expressing a philosophy, not a scientific reference. "But there are farms." Yes, there are. What good is a farm (yes, even a highly technologically advanced one) going to do you if you can't get the resources to feed/fuel/sustain your farm because the planet doesn't give those resources anymore?
2. "There is no way we will ever have a last fish or tree." Not possible to be true. If the planet gets much worse, vegetation will not be able to grow, and that includes trees. You can see a couple of references in the video to this degradation of greenery and water.
3. Don't be one of those people who say "hippie shit". Don't be that guy. Just don't, man. Why would you WANT to look like the bad guy?
4. About your conversation with Zerklass, you were being belligerent. His comment was 99% a Pulp Fiction quote. You just flipped completely off your rocker and attacked him with the might of a 1000 angry mothers. A bit extreme.

text:
I switched to a company called "Ethical Energy" that puts 100% wind power on the PA grid.¬† My electric bill dropped about 25% in the first month.¬† As my incandescent bulbs burn out, I'm replacing them with mostly LED bulbs, but some CFs as well.¬† The LED bulbs are compatible with dimmers like my X-10 switches.¬† The cost for the bulbs has really dropped and they last about 20 years or more.¬† You can get 60w of incandescent light out of a 7w LED light and it's full spectrum.¬†

But we're stuck between a rock and a fracking drill.¬† There's money in killing the environment and the people making it don't give a fucking damn what happens to the planet.¬† Ironically, most of the people in PA who are getting their water and land polluted beyond repair by fracking are right wing morons who only watch FOX and believe that there's no such thing as global climate change.¬† "Hey, it snowed, so global warming can't exist!"¬† Ironically, it's precisely because of global warming that has caused the polar vortex to shift south and has rerouted the gulf stream.¬†

Sadly, I'm expecting to see reports about "mysterious" birth defects in fracking-infested communities in the coming years.¬† The children deserve more than that fate.¬† But the parents to be don't seem bothered by it.¬† We've also got a soon to be ex-governor (Corbett) who is entirely bought and paid for by the fracking industry and PA is the ONLY state that doesn't have an extraction tax.¬† Wolf is up by 20 points and he'll change the tax situation for frackers, and make them pay for the damage they do.¬† Even that won't be enough, but it is at least a start.

VOTE!

text:
And that is the precise reason it is generally seen as more accurate to refer to the phenomenon as climate change than global warming. While it is proven that average temperatures are rising, climate change also causes other things, including extreme rainstorms, freezing temperatures (hence my first sentence), and tornadoes. The important points are that climate change is melting the ice caps, causing weather extremes and disrupting natural cycles and so killing off far too many species.
If you want evidence of climate change, here is a good article: http://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/

text:
Three inches of snow is called weather, not climate. There's a massive difference. And you might get away with inferring its a con if it was just a few climatologists reporting on climate change but it''s not, its 98% of every climatologist on the planet. And it's absolutely ridiculous to say they're making it up because they are paid to find climate change because they are not. They are paid to study the Earth's climate and climate change is what they are all discovering. You wouldn't go to an Oncologist and then not believe him when he tells you you have cancer because he's paid to find out whether you have cancer or not, so why use that argument against climatologist? Their jobs are not dependent on whether climate change is real or not so that argument is completely bogus.

Example of that terrible argument:

Climatologist: We've studied various samples from various locations and have conferred with a multitude of climatologists worldwide and the overall consensus of these studies all point to the indisputable fact that climate change is real and that it is happening right now.

MacabreHeritage: I don't believe you because you are paid to study the climate.

or

Doctor: I have visually examined you, taken x-rays, conferred with other doctors and have come to the conclusion that your arm has been cut off.

MacabreHeritge: I don't believe you because you are paid to find out if my arm is missing.

text:
¬†@Absaalookemensch¬†
Man-made climate change has generally been accepted by scientists for over two decades now. ¬†I (a 33 year old Brit) was, thankfully, well educated in the 1990s about the danger of climate change. ¬†But the last two decades have taught us that as individuals most of us (me included) are far too selfish to make enough of a change to our own lives to save the planet. ¬†We are past the stage of "well he's not reducing his footprint so why should I". ¬†At this stage, leaders leading by example is not what the world needs (although it certainly helps).

We need to tax the hell out of anything that causes significant CO2 emissions. ¬†Governments should make it so that individuals and businesses are forced to find alternative ways to shop/consume/travel/produce. ¬†That country's economy will take a short term blow but their alternative energy research will massively accelerate out of economic necessity. ¬†That brave government will have prepared their country for the future, helped to save the planet and probably become world leaders in renewable energy - the only type of energy that people will be using once the sea levels significantly rise, the polar ice caps melt, the water acidifies, etc.

My main concern is that there are still so many articulate, intelligent people like you who are dragging their heels. ¬†Change is coming. ¬†Neither believing in a god nor having lots of money is going to save our grandchildren from living on a ruined planet unless things happen soon. ¬†I am sure the worldwide marches last week are just the beginning. ¬†Nothing is more important than the future of our race.

The UK is having a General Election next year and I have never known so many of my friends and family to be so sure that they are voting for the Green party (or at least, are voting with the environment as their number one concern).

So, stop worrying about whether or not some people are or are not greener than you. ¬†Get politicians to legislate to save the planet.

author: easyDaMan

text:
¬†@easyDaMan¬†
I did not say we should not reduce pollution.
If the hypothesis is that pollution is causing Global Climate Change and there is much evidence to disprove the hypothesis, then you cannot scientifically state the hypothesis is correct.
And if you are willing to be unscientific in assuming the hypothesis is correct when it isn't, what other science are you willing to throw away for an agenda.
Start by being factual and honest.
Pollution has increased environmental CO2 levels.¬† The surface temperature of the earth has not changed in the past few decades.¬† The earth has experienced episodic fluctuations of temperature as evidenced by various studies.¬† The sun, our heat source, also has episodic thermal output variations, that seem to correlate with the earths temperature fluctuation, as seen by various studies. Thus CO2 "may" cause some variation in the planets temperature, but so too does the sun.
Since we have a significant increase in pollution attributed to global industrialization and utilization of stored energy, we could utilize cleaner energy sources (some of which are less expensive than current electrical power plants).
Then we could encourage, through tax incentives, people to convert from #1 Heating Oil (Diesel fuel), #2 Propane and Natural Gas and finally #3 Wood, in heating their houses and water, to electric.
Hybrid and electric personal transportation would also be encouraged through tax incentives.
This is all predicated upon the availability of cheap and abundant electricity.¬† The use of low pressure sodium reactors, either conventional nuclear or Thorium fueled.¬† Low pressure reactors are house sized, safer by at least a magnitude, more efficient, cheaper and use liquid sodium to transfer heat.¬† We have over 4,000 of fissionable material within the borders of the U.S and unlimited amounts of Thorium.
This also completely depends upon a prosperous and growing economy to allow millions to convert to electric.
But atmospheric pollution is only a fraction of the problem.¬† Overcoming individual greed, the lust to consume far in excess of what is needed, is the big problem.¬† And that you cannot mandate.
When I lived in Europe for several years people cheated on their pollution control laws.¬† The same who are unwilling or unable to do what is right are unwilling or unable to comply with heavy handed laws.¬† Irresponsible people use heating oil that has few taxes and drive diesel cars, then pump their heating oil into their cars.¬† They don't recycle, they pollute, they do what is in their nature and they find ways to go around the laws.¬† These irresponsible people know no political boundaries.¬† That is why the high priests of the green movement are among the biggest polluters.¬† But as a 600lb man writing a Diet Book has no credibility, neither do these "Do as I say, not as I do" charlatans.
So start by being honest.¬† If you base your foundation upon lies, lies are all you will garner.¬† And lied to you will be.

text:
¬†@Will C¬†
Get the left (where this is coming from) to comply with CO2 reductions and the Independents and right will follow.
I sequester more CO2 than we emit (due to land ownership).
Bot-that is the sweetest thing anyone has said to me for ages.¬† But no kiddo, I'm a died in the wool, true blue, 100% legal immigrant, naturalized American who grew up under communism.
I served our nation over 2 decades, through dozens of deployments to about 20 nations.
I get my data from NPR, MSNBC, CBS, ABC, Wall Street Journal, several other sources and a select few scientific journals.
A farmer learns quickly how to glean the harvest from the dross.¬† And I learned quickly how to identify disinformation, as I have studied it for almost 40 years.
A nutcase?¬† That is a matter of debate.
However, I have never been accused of not calling it like I see it and my vision is crystal clear.
In the end there are 2 kinds of people.
Those whose "Yes is their Yes and their No is their No" and those who twist the truth (liars).
I have done more than my fair share.
I do not believe the science supports the hypothesis.
But I do not see the left doing, just talking and polluting.
Even Al Gore, the "Pope" of Global Cooling...Global Warming...Global Climate Change pollutes more than dozens of ordinary citizens.

text:
¬†@*****¬†
And we had the coldest winter on record.¬†
The mean surface temperature has not risen, aside from ground monitoring stations that were built in open fields decades ago, but due to suburban growth now sit above paved parking lots or near artificial heating sources.
That's not to say that we haven't been in a warming cycle since about 1820.¬†
We may warm up a bit more or we may plateau and then head into a cooling cycle.
But "man made climate change gasses" were not abundant when the current warming cycle began.
To say man made CO2 emissions caused our 200 year warming trend is unproven.¬†
It may be the case, but it is not proven.
It is equally wrong to say we should not work to reduce pollution.
But reducing pollution is the right thing to do even if it is proven not to cause global cooling, warming or climate change.

text:
What climate change deniers fail to understand is the difference between cause and effect. What scientists do know as a fact is that increased CO2 emissions is going to cause SOMETHING. Why? It's actually very simple using elementary science education. Energy cannot be created nor destroyed. Massive amounts of energy was stored in the earth as fossil fuels and we've extracted that and burned massive amounts off as CO2. It has to go somewhere, and it's going into our atmosphere and insulating the earth. Plants cannot keep up with our burning and the CO2 levels steadily rise.¬†

Anyway, we know that SOMETHING bad is going to become of this though we can only predict. No one knows for sure exactly what's going to come of it and it aggravates me that so many people spend their time arguing about said predictions such as seas rising, massive disasters, etc. That's all wasted effort. Let's accept the science that we are in fact insulating the earth and either come up with a way to decrease emissions or to artificially clean the atmosphere ourselves somehow.¬†

text:
The earth is constantly being bathed in radiation of many sorts from the sun - light, ultraviolet, infrared, and so on.
Around 30% of this radiation is immediately reflected back into space, but ~70% is absorbed by the earth.This absorbed radiation is changed to infrared radiation, which is then radiated back into space (this absorbance/radiation is a different mechanism from simple reflection). Most of the gasses in the earth's atmosphere - O2, N2, etc. do not interact with this IR Radiation.

No, it was not. In other words, we are VERY rapidly approaching that amount of CO2.

text:
*sigh* another Al Gore fetishist. 

The father of the theory of man-made global warming is Svante Arrhenius, who developed and published the theory in 1896. He built on the earlier work of Fourier and Tyndall, and his calculations have turned out to be accurate. Over the course of the 20th century, the theory was tested many times, and in 1958, the first warnings about the warming, sea level rise, and ice melt that we're seeing now were first issued. 

Gore is merely a messenger.

You can also engage in local politics, and make sure you let your representatives know that action on the issue will draw your vote and your voice. This can help get state and local legislation that's better suited to the needs of your area than any national legislation would be. 

If you're genuinely interested in taking action, I would be happy to help you figure out what the best way is for YOU to go about it, or there are numerous resources online where you can do that yourself.
author: Alteredstory

text: (part two) The other thing that's within everybody's capability is education - learn about what's going on and tell others. Make it hard for people to just ignore the issue. Beyond THAT, you can get into community action - you might not be able to do something by yourself, but if 15, or 150 people pool their resources, you can do a lot. One example is a school that bought a couple wind turbines that now generate over 100k in profit for the school every year from electricity sales. (TBC)
author: Alteredstory

text: Responses vary depending on individual resources. Starting at the most basic level, it should be something that everybody considers when voting. Next up is simple things like changing how you use power (turning off lights, etc.). The impact of that is small, but when thousands of people start changing their habits in one area, they're more likely to in other areas. It creates a cultural shift that can lead to greater action. It's essentially peer pressure on a grand scale. (to be continued)

text:
(part two)

Those calculations by Svante Arrhenius have turned out to be very accurate. The discovery of a historical correlation between CO2 and temperature was merely one of many confirmations of that hypothesis. The current warming, which is in line with the calculations of physicists, based on the properties of the CO2 molecule, is another confirmation.
author: Alteredstory

text:
You seem to have missed out on the history of climate science. 

The first predictions of warming were in 1896, and were based on careful calculations of the thermal properties of CO2. 

At the time, the historical correlation of CO2 levels and temperature change was not known. The hypothesis that CO2 from burning fossil fuels was based on simple molecular physics - each molecule of CO2 can absorb and re-radiate heat at a known rate, therefor you can calculate how much warming comes from CO2.

text:
Yes, humans ARE causing this rapid heating of our climate. Sure, our climates have gotten warmer or cooler thousands or hundreds of thousands of years ago, but the change was incrementally smaller over larger periods of time. Never before has it been this rapid.

Now, water vapor is a defining factor, but it is also what is called a "positive feedback" to the problem. If we tip the scale with CO2 emissions, and that causes more water to evaporate every cycle, then you have a positive feedback.

text: That's not true. In fact, the opposite is true. Increased CO2 concentrations have been shown to increase nitrogen fixation and have no effect on the uptake of gaseous nitrogen. You can read about it here: treephys.oxfordjournals[dotorg]/content/24/3/323.full.pdf
author: MewCat100

author: MewCat100

text: Yes, the BP Oil spill was a tragedy, but it is specious to say that wind, tidal, and hydro do less damage. Hydro, in particular, does a great deal of damage in a number of different ways. I imagine they will be better, but that is not the argument being made.
author: MewCat100

text: ...that all important surplus electricity is then used to power massive air pumps that pressurise air into a storage unit. At night the air is slowly released and used to turn those same turbines which during the day generate electricity. author: cjbriggs88

text: A very valid point. What you do is you store the surplus electricity during the daytime and then use that stored energy to pick up the shortfall as generation decreases at night. The Spanish have a site that uses a system whereby the sunlight during the day is deflected (using mirrors that rack the Sun's movements) towards a toward containing -a viscous liquid of some sort, I don't recall- that gets extremely hot, heating water which turns turbines generating electricity.

text: Imagine a car. Think of the glass to be the greenhouse gases, and the upholstery to be the earth's surface. Glass allows transmission of only shortwave radiation, so incoming shortwave radiation from the sun enters the vehicle, is absorbed and heats the interior, then the interior reflects back longwave radiation, but it cannot easily transmit back through the glass. This is why your car heats so much with the sun out, and also why the earth is more responsible for it's warmth than the sun.

text: to clarify: if it takes as long to increase atmospheric CO2 from 560 to 1120 parts per million by volume (ppmv) as it did to rise from 280 to 560 ppmv, for example, then the associated warming at the Earth's surface will be roughly linear. p.s. There is warming in the pipeline, and we expect at least 3C for a doubling of CO2!
author: checkyoursources

text: I think you have  confused the idea of logarithmic temperature change relative to CO2. The basic idea is that small quantities of CO2 have a much larger effect when the baseline concentration is low. As the level of CO2 increases, the amount needed to generate more warming increases. So, a rise from 278 PPM to 288 PPM has more effect than a rise from 288 to 298 PPM. Thus, we have seen most of the 1C rise we will see before hitting 556 PPM.
author: MewCat100

text: Ah, what solutions are you referring to?
author: MewCat100

text: We already have solutions, we don't need any more time!
author: checkyoursources

text: Despite the logarithmic relationship between CO2 and surface temperatures, atmospheric CO2 levels are rising so fast that unless we dramatically decrease our emissions, global warming will accelerate over the 21st Century. "we have seen about 70% of the temperature rise we would expect", no, we have seen only 1C of 3C (33%) of the expected warming with doubled CO2. "Current levels of production" are not indicative of future rates!

We have gone from 278 PPM pre-industrial revolution to about 390 PPM. So, we have seen about 70% of the temperature rise we would expect as we approach  556 PPM. The thing is, at current levels of production it will take nearly a century to reach 556 PPM and nearly four centuries to reach the 1112 PPM to get 2 C rise in temp CONT

Warming is typically followed by cooling, and the last really major cooling resulted in an ice age which wiped out a considerable portion of life on Earth.

text:
I spent quite a while holding the opinion that nuclear power was the way to go, but I changed my mind for two reasons. 

The first is that implementation is simply not occurring. The majority of nuclear proponents that I talk to seem to care less about actually USING nuclear than they do about NOT using renewables. 

The second is that with potable water supplies dwindling, ANY risk of contamination has to be avoided. Nukes are water-intensive, and vulnerable to floods, and we can't risk that.

That makes more of the water in the poles fresh water, which doesn't circulate heat as well. So, all that heat will stay at the equator, and the further away regions will freeze to death. 
So, no need to choose between fire or ice. We'll die in both if this keeps up.

text: Agreed, but oceanic circulation resulting in worse winter weather doesn't = colder.  It means more extreme/unusual precipitation during cold months. text:
Several problems that I can come up with regarding the accuracy of the data are:
1. How accurate is it in determining the magnitude of the warming?
2. Have all major factors in temperature change been accounted for?
3. Does the data give us a good way of distinguishing natural from human causes?
4. Does the data demonstrate that CO2 is the gas to target or is it more likely that another substance is more important?
author: MewCat100

text: Well, the accuracy of the data does seem to be in some question, even among scientists who are proponents of AGW. The data seems to suggest the Earth is warming, but the question is, how much? The data does a very poor job at describing how much the Earth has warmed and an even poorer job at prognosticating, which is why many people disavow it altogether. The correct approach, from both sides, is to get better data that is free from bias. That is becoming harder to do as politics get in the way.

text:
The so-called "science" of global warming is affected by a number of things that introduce bias. Bias kills objective science, as it has in this case. Sources of bias include:
1. Political power to be gained from controlling carbon
2. The idea of "noble cause corruption"
3. More traditional forms of corruption
4. The standard reaction when someone's life's work is challenged
5. Traditional hubris on the part of many
6. Overreaching/overstating our abilities to measure changes.

This is politically incorrect. That is, climate change is not "our biggest challenge" yet, nor is it true that the earth is currently getting too hot.

The latter because the consensus among economist is that rising temperature is, on the whole, beneficial. At least up to 2*C, which will occur in 2060 according to the best guess by IPCC. (Google "What Nordhaus gets wrong about climate change" for sources.)

The former because of malaria, the slaughter in Darfur and millions dying in hunger.

"Science isn't good or bad. It's only true."

I'm not sure who said that first, but the point remains - It's up to us to decide how we make use of science discoveries. That's also why you see the rhetoric about science "informing" decisions, rather than "dictating" them.

The same research that enables atomic energy enables atomic bombs; the same research that enables laser readers (CDs, DVDs, etc.) enables laser guns; the same tech that powers cars powers harvester machines, etc.
